chunk-29ff428c0f4d133efd23bd4fcfedb0e9.description: The titular character of the story, a young boy from another planet who the Narrator encounters in the desert. Also refers to the narrative event that unfolds as the story of the book by Antoine de Saint-Exupery.
The author of 'The Little Prince' and a pilot by profession. He is also the narrator of the story, who crashed in the Sahara desert and later meets the Little Prince.

The first drawing made by the Narrator as a child, depicting a boa constrictor digesting an elephant. It was not understood by the grown-ups, leading the Narrator to make another drawing to clarify his point.
The second drawing made by the Narrator as a child, showing the inside of a boa constrictor to clarify his first drawing.

chunk-5d8e41f2d3eb00d7ae3492fa45376bdc.description: The Desert of Sahara is the location where the narrator had an accident with his plane, and where he meets the little prince. It is also where the narrator is stranded a thousand miles away from any human habitation.

The narrator is the person who had an accident in the Sahara and encounters the little prince, attempting to draw a sheep for him. He is also the one who mentions not having a mechanic or passengers with him, leaving him alone to attempt repairs on his plane.

The Little Prince is a mysterious small person who appears in the desert and asks the narrator to draw him a sheep. He engages in multiple interactions with the narrator, correcting his drawings and eventually receiving a drawing of a sheep that he likes.

The plane is the vehicle the narrator uses, which crashes in the Desert of Sahara, leading to the encounter with the Little Prince. It is also the plane whose engine is broken, forcing the narrator to attempt repairs in the desert.

The drawing of a sheep is the central theme in the interactions between the Little Prince and the narrator. The Little Prince repeatedly asks the narrator to draw a sheep, rejecting various attempts until he is satisfied with a drawing of a sheep inside a box.

chunk-3ad6a1b911b89af0f8782fc9fd4c585b.description: A character who owns an airplane and comes from a very small planet, known as Asteroid B-612. He is also referred to as 'the little prince' in the narrative.

The small home planet of The Little Prince, scarcely larger than a house, and also known as 'ASTEROID B-612'. It was discovered by a Turkish astronomer and was initially not believed due to his attire, but later accepted after presenting in European costume at the International Astronomical Congress.

chunk-b8046856f6dc60f84ab920815d8ad77f.description: Asteroid B-612 is the home planet of the little prince, described as being scarcely bigger than himself, and infested with the seeds of the baobabs which pose a threat to the entire planet if not controlled.

The Little Prince is the main character of the story, who lived on Asteroid B-612 and needed a sheep. He is portrayed as a figure who understands life and contrasts with grown-ups who only care about figures. He is also responsible for controlling the baobabs on his planet.

The Narrator is the author of the story, who recounts the experiences and conversations with the Little Prince and tries to remember him through drawings. The Narrator is also the one who provides the context and understanding of life, differentiating between children and grown-ups.

chunk-fb27acaa4829c48fcb11475510681661.description: The main character of the story, who provides insights about life, discipline, and the importance of attending to the baobabs on his planet. He also explains concepts like sunsets and the passage of time.

Invasive trees on the Little Prince's planet that can cause significant damage if not controlled, symbolizing the importance of discipline and timely action. They are also a danger to anyone who might get lost on an asteroid.
The home of the Little Prince, infested with baobabs, and serves as a setting to illustrate the dangers of neglecting responsibilities. It is also where he observes sunsets and twilight.
France and the United States are mentioned as geographical locations to explain the concept of sunsets by the Little Prince, where the sun sets over France when it is noon in the United States.
Sunset and twilight are events that the Little Prince enjoys watching, symbolizing his sadness and the passage of time. He can observe them whenever he likes on his planet.
Day is a part of the daily cycle that the Little Prince experiences on his planet, contrasting with the night and twilight.
The character who interacts with the Little Prince, learns about his life, and shares the story with the readers.
An animal that plays a significant role in the Little Prince's life, as it leads to the revelation of the secret about the thorns on flowers.

Flowers are plants that the Little Prince is curious about, particularly in relation to the sheep and their thorns. Thorns are a part of the flowers that the Little Prince questions the Narrator about, leading to a discussion on their purpose.
Plants that resemble young baobabs and are mentioned as part of the discipline the Little Prince must exercise in maintaining his planet.

chunk-7b0b95f03824488b77063e69940902c4.description: The main character of the story, who is curious about the world and has a unique perspective on what is important. He interacts with various entities, including the Rose, the Sheep, and the Red-Faced Gentleman, and learns valuable lessons about life and love.

A unique flower on the Little Prince's planet, which becomes significant to him and a source of his emotional attachment. The Rose symbolizes fragility, beauty, and the things that are important but often overlooked.

A character that poses a threat to the Rose, symbolizing the potential loss and the fragility of what the Little Prince holds dear. The Sheep also represents the indifference of nature and the potential for destruction.

The planet where the Narrator and the Little Prince are, and it serves as the setting for their interactions and discussions. Earth represents the adult world, with its focus on practical tasks and mundane concerns.

A concept that represents the difference between what adults often consider important and what the Little Prince values. It encompasses the adult preoccupation with practical tasks over more meaningful pursuits, as symbolized by the Bolt, the Hammer, and the Engine-Grease.

A symbol of the vastness of the universe and the homes of the flowers that the Little Prince cares about, representing the grandeur and the smallness of individual concerns. The Stars also symbolize the protective measures promised by the Narrator to the Little Prince, such as the Muzzle for the Sheep and the Railing for the Flower.

chunk-1558cc6e181ee78ffe222abcbc6f2d72.description: The main character who interacts with the flower, learns about love and relationships, and maintains his home planet.
A coquettish and vain character who has a complex relationship with the Little Prince, symbolizing love and vulnerability.
The home planet of the Little Prince, where he takes care of the flower, maintains the volcanoes, and pulls up baobab shoots.
Volcanoes on the Little Prince's planet, including active and extinct ones, which he cleans and uses for heating his breakfast.
A shelter that the Little Prince prepares for the Flower to protect her from the cold, symbolizing care and protection.

chunk-fad435ecfc8953f86da2a8a28753686f.description: The main character who travels to different planets, including the one ruled by the King, and has a conversation with the Flower about love and freedom.
A character who claims to rule over everything, including planets and stars, and is encountered by the Little Prince on one of the asteroids.
A proud and independent entity who has a conversation with the Little Prince about love and freedom, and decides to face the natural elements without protection.
Asteroids that the Little Prince visits, with the first one being inhabited by the King.
The means of protection shown by the Flower, symbolizing her defense mechanisms and representing her four thorns.
An event that the Little Prince wishes to watch multiple times, symbolizing the longing for beauty and the passage of time.

chunk-57c45104799c14221f4f527b116a21c9.description: The King is a character who claims absolute authority and expects obedience from his subjects. He interacts with The Little Prince on The Planet, symbolizing the concept of authority and control. He is also the one who appoints The Little Prince as Minister of Justice and later as Ambassador, attempting to retain some control over him.

The Little Prince is the protagonist who visits different planets, including the one inhabited by The King, seeking to understand the nature of authority and relationships. He is appointed as Minister of Justice by The King and later as Ambassador, but ultimately decides to continue his journey, reflecting on the strangeness of grown-ups.

The Conceited Man is a character who believes everyone is an admirer and seeks admiration. He is encountered by The Little Prince on his journey to different planets, providing another perspective on vanity and self-importance.

The Planet is the location where The King and The Little Prince interact, symbolizing the concept of authority and control. It is also the place where The Little Prince is appointed as Minister of Justice and later as Ambassador by The King.

chunk-dafdab97a777a8c564dbe500c68e7111.description: The main character of the story, who visits different planets and interacts with various individuals, learning about their peculiarities.
A character on one of the planets visited by the Little Prince, who is obsessed with receiving admiration and praise.
A character on another planet, who drinks to forget his shame of drinking, representing a cycle of addiction.
A character on a fourth planet, preoccupied with counting stars and claiming ownership over them, symbolizing materialism and obsession with wealth.

chunk-dafdab97a777a8c564dbe500c68e7111.entity_name: The Planet of the Conceited Man
chunk-dafdab97a777a8c564dbe500c68e7111.description: The location where the Little Prince interacts with the Conceited Man, learning about vanity and the need for genuine connection.
Where the Little Prince finds the Tippler engaged in a cycle of drinking to forget his shame, representing the futility of certain coping mechanisms.
The location of the Little Prince's encounter with the Businessman, who is preoccupied with owning stars, symbolizing greed and the absurdity of materialism.

chunk-bbd4bb00edb95d3a6a2320a2c0af011f.description: The main character who questions the grown-ups' perspectives on matters of consequence and explores different planets, including meeting the Businessman, the Lamplighter, the King, the Conceited Man, and the Tippler.
The smallest of all planets, with just enough room for a street lamp and a lamplighter, and has a rapid rotation that affects the Lamplighter's work.
A character on the Fifth Planet who follows orders to light and extinguish a street lamp, finding his work meaningful despite its repetitive nature.
A character who claims to own the stars and is interested in matters of consequence, such as wealth and ownership.
A possession of the Little Prince, which he waters every day, symbolizing care and usefulness in ownership.
Possessions of the Little Prince, which he cleans out every week, representing the idea that ownership should be of some use, including the Extinct Volcano.

chunk-912d639f475f58f3a998ccb1dc84c90c.description: The Lamplighter is a character who is bound by orders to light and extinguish his lamp every minute due to the rapid rotation of his planet, leaving him no time to rest. He is a man who is both faithful to his duty and desires rest, finding solace in sleep. Despite the scorn he might receive from other characters like the King, the Conceited Man, the Tippler, and the Businessman, the Little Prince finds him to be the only one who does not seem ridiculous, as he is thinking of something else besides himself.

The Geographer is an old gentleman who writes voluminous books and claims to know the location of all seas, rivers, towns, mountains, and deserts, but has not explored them himself. He is a scholar who receives explorers in his study, asking them questions and noting down their recollections. He is concerned with the moral character of the explorers to ensure the accuracy of his geographical records, as an explorer who lies or drinks too much could bring disaster to his books.

chunk-d2ad187037f2e5fcdf28bec8079f024c.description: The main character who interacts with various entities, including the geographer, and shares his experiences and thoughts about his planet and a flower.
A character who is interested in recording permanent features of places and interacts with the Little Prince to learn about his planet.
A planet with a diverse population, setting for the lamplighters' narrative, and mentioned for its size and the collective entities of its inhabitants.

A collective entity of lamplighters responsible for lighting street lamps before the invention of electricity, symbolizing a now-obsolete profession, and mentioned in the context of their global sequence of actions.
A character that the Little Prince encounters, contributing to the narrative of the story.

chunk-e8e0dbcdcb0182c36c60e66709e40b50.description: The protagonist of the story, who travels to Earth and interacts with various entities, seeking understanding and companionship.
A snake encountered by the Little Prince in the desert, who engages in conversation and offers insights into the nature of humanity and the Little Prince's journey.

The planet where the Little Prince lands, inhabited by humans and various other entities, and serves as the setting for much of the narrative. Africa is a continent on Earth, identified by the Snake as the specific location where the Little Prince has arrived. The desert is a barren and uninhabited area of Earth where the Little Prince finds himself, symbolizing loneliness and the absence of human contact.
A three-petal flower encountered by the Little Prince in the desert, representing a brief encounter and a source of information about humans.
A hypothetical public square large enough to contain all of humanity, used to illustrate the relative smallness of the Earth's surface.
Adults mentioned in the narrative, who are characterized by their disbelief and self-importance, contrasting with the perspective of the Little Prince.
A type of tree referenced to emphasize the grown-ups' self-perception of importance, comparing their imagined size to that of baobabs.
A group of travelers that the Flower once saw passing, symbolizing the rarity and transient nature of human encounters in the desert.
Three volcanoes known to the Little Prince, which are small enough to come up to his knees, representing the familiarity and scale of his own planet.
A high mountain range that the Little Prince climbs in an attempt to see the whole planet and its people, symbolizing his quest for understanding and companionship.
An echo that the Little Prince encounters on the mountain, which repeats his words, highlighting the lack of original thought or companionship on the planet.
A garden where the Little Prince discovers many roses, leading to a realization about the uniqueness and value of his own rose back home.

chunk-b65f42e117978522f30d03260998b9c1.description: The protagonist of the story, who discovers a garden of roses and later befriends a fox, learning about the nature of relationships, uniqueness, and the adult human world.
A group of roses that the Little Prince encounters, which all look like his own flower, leading to a realization about the nature of uniqueness and the event where he discovers them.
A wise fox that the Little Prince meets, who teaches him about the importance of establishing ties, the concept of taming, and the event of their interaction.
The home planet of the Little Prince, where he had a unique flower and three small volcanoes, and where he had conversations about taming with the fox.
The location where the fox is found, under which the Little Prince and the fox have their conversation about taming and relationships.
The fields of grain mentioned by the fox, which are金黄色 and will remind the fox of the Little Prince after they discuss taming each other.
Mentioned by the Little Prince as the place where one sees all sorts of things, contrasting with his own planet and where he encounters the abodes of men and the garden of roses.
The animals that men raise, as mentioned by the fox, representing a part of the human world's interests.

chunk-ac2a150023941d9ab7a2215e336f2400.description: The main character who encounters various individuals and learns life lessons throughout his journey, including the value of friendship and responsibility for his rose.
A character who sorts out travelers and sends off trains, representing a role in the transportation system and discussing the nature of human satisfaction and pursuit.
A character who sells pills to quench thirst, emphasizing the value of time-saving in society and the different perspectives on how to use saved time.
The geographical location where the narrator and the Little Prince search for a well, symbolizing a challenging environment and the hidden value it contains.
An event that highlights the desperation of the narrator and the Little Prince for water in the desert, representing their quest for survival and the deeper meaning of hidden values.
The character who has an accident in the desert and shares experiences and conversations with the Little Prince, providing insights into life and friendship.
A friend of the Little Prince, mentioned in the context of the value of friendship and the understanding of life's deeper meanings, including the concept of taming and responsibility.
The event that strands the narrator, leading to the meeting with the Little Prince and their subsequent adventures, which shape the narrator's understanding of life and relationships.

A central concept in the story, driving the actions of the narrator and the Little Prince as they search for water in the desert, symbolizing the quest for essential needs and the deeper search for meaning.

Represents a hidden value or secret, which in the context of the story, is likened to the well hidden in the desert by the Little Prince, symbolizing the unexpected treasures found in life's journeys.
Symbolizes a unique and cherished possession, as the Little Prince feels responsible for his rose, indicating the importance of care, attachment, and the personal significance of relationships.

chunk-e64f383d078d44dd529888e2e15ddb1b.description: A character who shares his wisdom about the beauty of the desert, the importance of looking beyond the visible, and his loyalty to a rose, symbolizing love and responsibility.
A geographical location that holds a sense of mystery and enchantment, symbolizing the hidden beauty of invisible things, and is also the setting for the narrator and the Little Prince's journey.

The storyteller who shares his experiences and insights with the Little Prince, reflecting on the journey and the search for meaning, and who is also reminded of his childhood memories and the joy of receiving gifts.

A significant location in the story where the narrator and the Little Prince find water, symbolizing the fulfillment of a quest, and is unique due to its setting without a village, contrasting with the wells of the Sahara.
Objects that are part of the well mechanism, contributing to the song and the effort of drawing water, symbolizing the tools for obtaining something precious.

chunk-243e3422cccbb06851cec237f231f0d6.description: A character who is afraid yet able to laugh, sharing a deep connection with the Narrator. He discusses the significance of laughter, friendship, and the stars, and is associated with a sheep, a box, and a muzzle. The Little Prince also has a unique perspective on the stars, which he shares with the Narrator, and is concerned about the蛇's potential threat to the Narrator.
The place where the Little Prince arrived a year ago, referenced in the context of his journey and the location of his star.
Significant to the Little Prince as it is associated with his home, mentioned in relation to the time of his arrival on Earth and his eventual departure.
A creature of concern for the Little Prince, as it poses a potential threat to the Narrator and is mentioned in the context of their final meeting.
An entity that the Little Prince has, significant in his interactions with the Narrator and symbolizing his care and responsibility. It is associated with a box and a muzzle.
A location associated with the Little Prince's story, possibly where he encountered the snake and is part of his narrative with the Narrator.
A group mentioned by the Little Prince, who view the stars as guides in their journeys.
A group referenced by the Little Prince, who see the stars as problems to be solved, indicating an academic or intellectual perspective.
People who the Narrator will have after knowing the Little Prince, as they will share in the joy of looking at the stars and laughing.
A character mentioned in the Little Prince's analogy about the different perspectives on the stars, representing a materialistic view.

chunk-07773724040c368d76f9480c21f26bb0.description: A character who is responsible for his flower and has a deep connection with the narrator. He returns to his home planet after his encounter with the narrator and is associated with the stars.
The person recounting the story of the Little Prince and his experiences, who is left wondering about the fate of the Little Prince's flower and the sheep.

chunk-07773724040c368d76f9480c21f26bb0.entity_name: The Little Prince's Planet (The Planet, The Sheep's Planet)
chunk-07773724040c368d76f9480c21f26bb0.description: The home of the Little Prince, where he returns after his encounter with the Narrator, and the location of the Flower and Sheep, which is a source of concern for the Narrator.
A character that the Little Prince is responsible for and cares deeply about, which might have been eaten by the Sheep, causing the Narrator to wonder about the state of the Little Prince's Planet.
A character that potentially poses a threat to the Little Prince's Flower, residing on the Little Prince's Planet and causing concern for the Narrator.
The geographical location where the Little Prince's story took place and where the narrator hopes to find him again.
A celestial body that the Narrator associates with the Little Prince and listens to at night, symbolizing the Little Prince's return to his home planet.
An object that the Narrator drew for the Little Prince's sheep, but forgot to add a leather strap, leading to concerns about the safety of the Little Prince's Flower.
An object used by the Little Prince to protect his flower every night, symbolizing the care he has for his Flower.
The setting of the story, where the Little Prince's Planet and the Sheep's Planet are located, and the context for the Narrator's contemplation about the fate of the Little Prince's Flower.
Mentioned as those who will never understand the importance of whether the Sheep has eaten the Flower, representing the lack of understanding and empathy in adults.
